poem:
Outpatient  
  
An Olive seeks  
the bruise-black truth—  
in halls of silent  
monitors' hum,  
where lives rhyme  
in whispered breaths.  
  
What feels forever,  
flickers, and ends.  
In this murmur of  
wilted skin,  
she finds her  
Pulitzer—  
a forgotten voice,  
a gentle nod  
to what we  
cannot speak.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Outpatient review – a journalist seeks the inside scoop on death ‘It’s weird we don’t talk about it,” declares journalist Olive, the alter-ego of writer and performer Harriet Madeley. Sick of reporting on Love Island, she wants to write about something worthy of a Pulitzer prize: death. Specifically, our societal reluctance to broach the subject. She visits a hospital to get the inside scoop from dying people. But she’s also having symptoms of her own". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
